name: North American Porcupine
description: Though resembling Old World porcupines, it is closer to guinea pigs. Its quills have tiny barbs. It is mostly brown-gray, with yellow-striped hairs and quills on its back tipped with white.
spread_note: Nearly all of North America except the northernmost regions, south to northern Mexico
food_note: Various plant parts including needles and tree bark
image_alt: North American Porcupine, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 65–68 cm, tail length 14.5–30 cm, shoulder height up to 30 cm, weight 3.5–7 kg
attractions: It doesn’t dig burrows but climbs excellently, equipped with long, sharp claws and adhesive palms and soles. It sleeps in trees, curled into a ball, often on surprisingly thin branches.
breeding: We kept porcupines from 1958–1993 near the main entrance. After a decade-long break, more arrived in 2003, with the first successful breeding in 1959.
